item.title: Graduation
item.description: ðŸŽ“ Graduated early from UCSD! Huge thanks to the incredible faculty at HDSI for making the beginning of my data science career a magical experience.

item.title: USRA NAMS at NASA Ames
item.description: Began a USRA NAMS project at NASA Ames. I’m researching ideal distributed data storage solutions and benchmarks for efficient ML/data workflows in their NAS division. It’s a small world after all, so we’re actually taking inspiration from the PRP (home to the Nautilus cluster and AR-NOC wouldn’t ya know it ðŸ˜‰)

item.title: Feedback
item.description: The student feedback collected by the data science student reps has seen the light of day! We presented our analysis of the last year of feedback to the data science curriculum meeting.

item.title: HDSI Data Science Capstone
item.description: For our data science capstone we’re building a tool to mitigate bias in network conditions while collecting data. Follow along here
Happy New Year! ðŸŽ‰

item.title: Arnoc Demo
item.description: We gave our official update report and demo slides for AR-NOC. First time I’ve worked with Unreal Engine!

item.title: AR-NOC
item.description: Began data pipelining work for the AR-NOC team at Nautilus. The NSF wants us to create a no-setup-required virtual environment for VR and AR data visualization.

item.title: Textbook
item.description: Officially started working on the new introductory data science textbook, “Dive into Data Science”

item.title: QWERTY vs Dvorak
item.description: Why are we stuck typing on the same keyboard layout that was invented for the earliest typewriters? The Dvorak keyboard layout is fabled to be much more efficient… come play with this interactive data visualization and put that claim to the test!

item.title: Thoughts on COVID-19 and the future of teaching
item.description: Amidst the doom and gloom around coronavirus, I invite you to entertain some potential silver linings with me. With universities transitioning all courses online, teaching strategies likely won’t return to “normal” once we recover from the pandemic. But might they actually get better? I’m preparing to TA for a now-online course next quarter, and I’ve discussed the following topics with a handful of my professors: On teaching approaches: Flipped classroom to teaching seem promising, but they lack widespread experimentation and support.

item.title: How an Amazon Alexa skill can open the door to data-driven medical insights
item.description: There are a huge number of “minor symptoms” in the world that go largely unreported. Sore throats, sniffles, dull pains, chest pressures, headaches… the list goes on. These symptoms are generally not going to prompt a patient to call up their doctor’s office. Nor is the patient likely to remember them at all once their next appointment finally comes around. Doctors wish they could change this. We’ll explore how we can change this, and examine the effects of widespread symptom reporting from a data science perspective.

item.title: This website.
item.description: I programmed this website using Hugoâ€”an open-source static site builderâ€”and created my own custom themes and scripts. Check out the code on GitHub!

item.title: The Verbosified Works on A.I. Space Rovers
item.description: I (ab)used OpenAI’s GPT-2 modelâ€”the one that’s “too dangerous to release”â€”to make an art piece in which the AI attempts to double the word count of an essay. The model can easily become too creative, though!

item.title: What Ignited My Love For Data Science
item.description: Starting by outlining the purpose of data science in today’s world, this brief talk by Parker Addison sheds light into what ignited an interest in observing, analyzing, and communicating data. This was scheduled as the first talk in a series of Ignite Talks with a theme of discovering and pursuing career paths. Ignite Talks are like super-fast TED talksâ€”a speedy style of presentation in which slides advance automatically every 15 seconds, resulting in a 5-minute total run time.

item.title: Sharing the Road
item.description: Bikes and cars don’t mix well. Turns out there’s data to prove that.

item.title: Neural Network Visual
item.description: Education in Machine Learning has experienced incredible growth. To aid the educational cause, we created an interactive, 3D visual editor for simple neural network models.

item.title: Ouch! That Hurts
item.description: We created an Amazon Alexa skill which enables patients to easily report systems without needing to keep a journal or call the doctor. By making it extremely easy to report such symptoms, we could collect a plethora of data that could be used to help predict and diagnose symptoms in the future.

item.title: Indeed Job Search City Recommender
item.description: We were given an anonymized dataset from indeed.com and asked to create a business pitch. We created an algorithm to rank and recommend cities that have the best prospects for a given job industry.
